Name: David D
Title: An ancient step well in Delhi
Review: This is a step well that is said by some to date from very ancient times. In its current form however it dates from the time of the Delhi Sultanate. The step well itself is quite large and visually very impressive. There are some ruined buildings near it, and the overhanging tress are often filled with parrots.

Name: Woodstag
Title: New Delhi Stepwell
Review: Agrasen Ki Baoli is an historical and huge step well situated in New Delhi area near our Claridges Hotel location. Great architecture to admire and relaxing place to sit for a few moments.

Name: Satish C
Title: Stepwell in heart of Delhi
Review: Place to visit for those interested in architecture / history. This is not a huge stepwell compared to those in Rajasthan or Gujrat but one of the few remaining in and around Delhi. We visited on a Sunday but with intermittent showers the place was not crowded. Suggest getting dropped off or walking as there's no parking facility and this is on a very narrow street.

Name: Lakshmi Biradar
Title: Stepwell with 100+ steps, one time visit place
Review: Agrasen Ki Baoli is a  wide historical step well in New Delhi. It is very located very near to Connaught Place. It was originally built by the legendary king Agrasen. It is open daily from 9am to 5.30pm. Various Bollywood films such PK starring Aamir Khan and Sultan starring Salman Khan. It was also featured in the 2017 Sridevi thriller Mom. This step well had 100+ steps. Weekends it will be too crowded.

Name: Hến M
Title: Beautiful place
Review: There was a “wow” reaction when you first see this paoli. It’s really beautiful. The architect is photogenic and incredible. The day I came is rainy, not crowded so it brought me the calm and nostalgic feeling when I visited. No tickets needed and they open at 9 AM.

Name: Ambarish2012
Title: Little gem
Review: Most tourists do not know of this place. But it is not just a beautiful place but also an architectural marvel.Quite close to Jantar Mantar. So try to include it in your Sightseeing of Delhi

Name: Surya Katakam
Title: Believed that this Baoli is build during Mahabharata time
Review: This is well maintained Well which was used to store the water during those olden days. Nothing much to see here other than photography. Best part of this place is it is well maintained step well with mesmerized architecture surrounding all 4 sides.Most of the tourists visit this place for photo shoot and nothing much here to see. if you don't have time better you can skip this place. This is on parallel road to Jan path and near to all main tourist spots so it will not take much time to you to reach this place. There is no parking place near this place so please note the same if you are travelling with your own vehicle.Interesting Facts about this place:1. A Baoli means Stepwell in Used language of North India. It is believed that this was commissioned by King Agrasen around 3000 BC and is renovated in 14th Century by the Agarwal community.  It is step well commissioned by Agrasen hence it is called as Agrasen Ki Baoli. 2. This is a 60 meter long and 15 meter wide step well having total 108 steps located near Jan path road. It also has three levels and each of them has nice architecture side walls3. This location is famous for Bollywood Movie shootings. PK, Sultan, Jhoom Barabar Jhoom and Mom are some of the famous movies which are having this place in some scenes.4. Archeological Survey of India is protecting this Monument. In total there are 14 Baoli's in side Delhi which are survived and now protected by Archaeological Survey of India. Out of those 14 Baoli's this is the one which is most visited and well maintained one.Visiting timings:All 365 days from morning 09:00 am to  Evening 05:30 pm

Name: Legend H
Title: Amazing accent monuments
Review: Amazing nice & quaint tourist attraction. It'll be peaceful with no people around if you reach here early before 9 am becouse after many n many people are here. At most, you can get some quiet time here. But, there are better places to get some peace. So, to be honest, it's not worth the time if you are a backpacker.

Name: Praveen K
Title: Unique utility archaeological site
Review: This place is in situated near cannuaght place, thus it is very assesible by  all modes of transport.  Parallel road to Janpath , besides KG Marg. It is situated in the by lanes and a fine motorable road takes you there. There is no parking but ad there is no other market or residential colony one can trickle down by walking, bike and other vehicles to make a visit. The place provided you serene environment and immediately takes you the past. You also left amazed at the to type utilities built by our previous generations who were appreciative both of societal needs and culture as well

Name: A Choudhury
Title: Old Step Well
Review: Located near Connaught Place, it is a step well used to store water in those days. It is basically flocked by couples and young people. Many movie sequences have been shot here. Not recommended for people who have a problem with climbing steep steps. There is no entry fee and photography is permitted.

Name: skagarwal74
Title: Great treat to watch
Review: Actually named "Ugrasen Ki Baoli" is a great treat to watch and not known to many people. The place is not far from India gate or Jantar mantar and one must visit this small place just for its uniqueness  and photography.The place is not spreadout. Rather there are steep stairs where one can sit and relax. There is no entrance fee here.

Name: K S
Title: Must visit
Review: If you're in Delhi and want to see something mind-blowing then please visit this place. It's close to cannaught place. Thanks to our tour guide we were able to see this marvelous monument.

Name: Tissa.travels
Title: 14th century well
Review: 14th century well in New Delhi, not too far from both India Gate and Connaught Place. Nice architecture and a great place to escape the busy city and get out of the sun.

Name: Anjan Sengupta
Title: A hidden gem....
Review: Not all people visiting Delhi have an idea of this hidden place. This is located at the heart of Delhi very near to Cannaught Place and can be reached in 10 minutes from there with an auto rickshaw. The design of this step well is very unique and it feels like entering a fort when you start going down the steps. This is an ideal place to sit and relax with family and click some memorable pictures..

Name: MONA .
Title: Mystical "Agrasen Ki Baoli"
Review: It is noted to be one of the most haunted destination in India Built By King Agrasen during the time of Mahabharata.Its a step well lined by 108 steps and paranormal activities experience differs from person to person.Due to its Mesmerizing Architecture Many Bollyhood  shooting has been done in this Location.

Name: Vikas Singh
Title: Step well in heart of New Delhi
Review: It is named after the legendary king Raja Agrasen (or Raja Ugrasen) of Agroha, who also happens to be the founder of Agarwal community. It measures 60 m in the north – south direction and is 15 m wide, and is made of rubble masonry. On the south west corner of the Baoli is a small mosque. The mosque is approached by a triple arched entrance but the arch on the southern side has long collapsed, along with the portions of the ‘whale back’ roof. Three of the four red sandstone pillared columns, that supported the arches, stands to this day. On the northern end of the Baoli is the circular well, measuring 8 m in diameter. The top of the well is covered with an iron grill preventing people from falling. The well is connected to the rectangular passage by shafts.On the southern side is a flight of 108 steps descending to the base of the Baoli.

Name: Brun066
Title: A wonderful mixture of utilitarian purposes and refined aesthetic solutions.
Review: Even before my trip to northern India I knew about the existence of "baoli", or stepwells, as a characteristic of this part of India, plagued by seasonal drought. I had in fact heard about it from an architect friend who had visited many of them, and had illustrated their features to me.Therefore, at the time of my visit to Delhi, I didn't miss out on this baoli, so central, relatively close to Connaught Place.It is relatively recent, compared to the average period of construction of the baoli (which would have been documented since the second century AD), dating back "only" to the fourteenth century.It certainly doesn't have the monumental, breathtaking grandeur of basins such as the Abaneri or Patan baoli. Unlike the latter, it's in fact long and very narrow: qualities that contrast with the depth of it, and make it almost a disturbing "crack" in the earth, in which you descend to the bottom with apprehension (not recommended for those suffering from claustrophobia).I started from this visit full of admiration for the wonderful mix that this work (as well as other similar ones) presents between utilitarian purposes and refined aesthetic solutions.

Name: AZCasualTraveler
Title: Interesting Centuries Old Architecture
Review: In India, it has been estimated that there are about 100 of these centuries old "Step Well" structures - where well water was once obtained by simply walking down the "steps" to the water's edge.  The Agrasen Ki Baoli - Leamigo Step Well is probably the most famous of the India "Step Wells" - there have been several Bollywood movies made at this location.  This Well is also centrally located in New Delhi.The architecture of this "Step Well" is impressive for such an ancient structure and it is very nice to look at and take in the thought of how many people in the past had made the trip down the Steps just to get water for their daily lives.  Interesting!

Name: Ayushi Dixit
Title: Dissappointed
Review: Well , i was rather dissappointed after visiting this place. But what can you expect? Itz a well and a well that beautiful is worth it right ?But i expected it to be big like other monuments in delhi.

Name: Mike X
Title: Nice break
Review: Free, easy to find and beautiful. If you're not visiting any other stepwells in India, for sure give this a shot. Mostly locals.

Name: Mohit
Title: Average. Good for a short visit. Free entry. Suitable location.
Review: There nothing much to see or experience here. The best part of the monument is that location. It's a convenient 10 minutes walk from CP. Also there is no entry fees for the monument. There are three levels with long stairs in the middle. Unfortunately, the access to different levels is restricted. Although it does not stop people to go to these levels for pictures but please be an educated traveller and not cross the makeshift barricades to access the levels.Baoli is a rajasthani word which means a well with staircases and that's what this place is. There is a well at the bottom of the steps. The steps are pretty steep as some places so if you have any knee problem then avoid getting down as it would be difficult to get back up. This place is also a hub for pigeons who like to defecate on tourists and there has been no attempt made to counter that problem. Seems the government of Delhi and ASI does not care much about this monument.Overall, you may spend 15 minutes to half an hour here. Take a couple of pictures and back to your merry way. I am really not sure why this monument is considered as a "hidden gem". There is no gem here honestly.

Name: Roshni S
Title: A hidden gem in the heart of Delhi
Review: Surrounded by modern buildings located on Hailey Road, the Ugrasen ki Bauli is a great place for tourists and to hang around. But the steps are plenty and steep so come wearing proper footwear.

Name: suzirosie
Title: Nice place to visit
Review: I stopped here for a quick visit on my way to Connaught Place. It's not a big sight but architecturally I think worth a look at. It's nicely maintained and you can take some good photos if you get there early when it's less busy.

Name: RicherTrips
Title: Worth a short stop
Review: In our itinerary, we had scheduled a visit to a huge and famous step well, Chand Baori, but our local guide recommend to make a short stop in this one. It was a surprise to find this archeological site in the center of Connought Place, surrounded by buildings. For a start, this well origins are lost in time. Nobody knows when it was constructed.  Our guided pretended it was 2 thousand years old, but it was rebuilt on the 14th century.

Name: JP F
Title: A place to see
Review: A little unknown but interesting site in Delhi.  It was a way to see a step well (old time sewer ) with amazing architecture .  Climb the steps if you can

Name: Elvin D
Title: Awesome
Review: I went there by 7.30am .It was not much crowded, very nice to take photos . Slowly crowd started to form. Must visit place if you are in Delhi

Name: Gidons51
Title: Surprisingly Beautiful attraction to visit shortly
Review: This is a very nice old fountain that 140 stairs Lead down steeply to get the water . Surprisingly how impressive this is . Built in the 15 century to fill the water needs at that time . Take a few minutes to visit . No entry charge .

Name: markeric
Title: A little hidden gem.
Review: This place wasn’t on our radar but our taxi driver suggested it and we were very glad he did. You won’t spend long here but it’s very interesting and tucked away where you wouldn’t otherwise know it was there.Definitely worth putting on your ‘to see’ list!

Name: lemotka
Title: Hidden gem !
Review: It is a step well , but what a step well ! If you stay in Central Delhi , this is literally a walking distance from Connaught place ! Grab a tuk tuk and visit it ! Serene and simply amazing !

Name: namit1707
Title: Stepwell
Review: Sitiuated in the heart of capital of india its an ancient well, its a great place to visit by ancient architecture lover and historical lover. Take extra care if youare travelling with kids and senior citizens. The structure is well built. The entry to this place is free and the entrance doesn’t  gives you a clue, what are youabout to see inside, the road is bit congested where the entrance of this monument is there. Its an offbeat place in delhi which is not known to most of the people.This place is also having metro connectivity, 5 minutes walk from Barakhamba road metro station.

Name: macedonboy
Title: Stepwell
Review: The Agrasen ki baoli is a stepwell near Connaught Place of all places. Despite being devoid of decorations, the architecture of the stepwell is interesting, especially for it’s photogenic qualities. The top 3 levels and walkways and niches arranged around the side of the well, while the lowest level doesn’t have these features.The well is worth visiting when in Delhi, especially as it’s only about a 15 minutes walk south of Connaught Place.

Name: shirinlalkaka
Title: Amazing
Review: It's very beautiful. Definitely worth going and seeing. Unfortunately what used to be the well, is now covered with plastic bottles and other such rubbish.

Name: Ibis L
Title: Fourth of the three Baolis we visited
Review: One of our goals during our visit to India was to see as many step wells as we could.  We were able to see 4 of them and even though Agrasen Ki Baoli was our fourth one, it did not disappoint. In fact, they were all different and each one very beautiful in their own way.  An additional bonus is that as you admire the beautiful architecture, you can also see how  many of the locals interact and enjoy the place.  Highly recommended.

Name: MaitraSN
Title: Lovely and Nostalgic Place to visit
Review: Will kinda give a Rajasthan feeling. Designed differently than those in Rajasthan. The stairs in here goes straight downwards from one direction only Different from all directions that we generally see in the desert state.Lovely structure. Will be fascinated once you go all the way down and look up.Just enjoyyy

Name: Mags S
Title: Stepwell
Review: Step-wells are not well known structures to many tourists - this is an unusual example besides storing water it was a place for travellers to rest. Well preserved. Free to enter it is well worth a visit

Name: Journeyager
Title: Interesting free site
Review: After having to pay for almost every sites in Rajasthan and Agra, we told our Delhi driver to take us to free sites only and he brought us here. I enjoyed the movie PK and was quite excited that this was one of the sites where PK was shot. It was a Sunday, hence quite crowded. There are about 108 steps and some are quite steep. The well at the end of it is empty.

Name: Gursharan Bahia
Title: Bahia
Review: Awsm ❤One of the best destinations in Delhi. Though not much publicized but visited by a number of tourists and locals . Eight centuries old stone structures. Seasonal water collection chamber with steps down .Very well approached and excellent Photography.

Name: Colin W
Title: An interesting place to visit
Review: After several visits to India I have just become aware of step wells in general. This is a very impressive structure and a good example of how rain water was stored. Very photogenic and a great spot for couples

Name: scott j
Title: With a visit
Review: Only a 15 or so minute walk from Connaught Place. Go early and beat the crowds for the best photo opportunities as it does get quite crowded. Entry is free.  It's a beautiful structure to see

Name: jazsacher
Title: Incredible Site !!
Review: I was literally overwhelmed with my visit to Agrasen Ki Baoli.  I came early in the morning and wasn't expecting much as I've visited other wells in India in the past.  But this place took my breathe away.... literally.  First off, we were the first ones here since it was early morning and we had the place to ourselves and therefore took some amazing shots in the process.  Secondly, this place is like a living, breathing optical illusion.  It seems to change appearance as you looked at it from different angles.  I've never seen anything quite like it.  And traveling down to the bottom of the wall and smelling the scent of bats and taking shots from there was amazing as well.  Visting Agrasen Ki Baoli was one of the highlights of my visit to India and I won't soon forget the experience.  But as I said, get there early.  Too many tourists there will ruin the experience.  You'll thank me later!

Name: ashishdeora123
Title: great
Review: The super hit Bollywood film PK gave a supreme turning point for an important architectural monument of India that is Agrasen ki Baoli in Delhi it will be open all days of the week from 07:30 am to 06:00 pm There is no entry fee needed to visit the well.

Name: Albia-Newton
Title: Nice old well
Review: The best preserved step well in DelhiVery popular with visitors at the weekend Free admission Easy access from metro. Not far from Connaught Place

Name: mrsaerophile
Title: Peaceful & Tranquil
Review: Agrasen Ki Baoli is a hidden gem in the heart of busy Delhi.Tucked away down an urban street, this stepwell is well worth a visit.Entry is free and there are some amazing photo opportunities to be had.

Name: 792Carol_H
Title: Worth the Visit
Review: Agrasen Ki Baoli is a heritage stepwell 60m long and 15 m wide which was built in the 1400's. The structure is made of red stone and is partly immersed in water.This Baoli,(well) with 108 steps, is among a few of its kind in Delhi. The visible parts of this historical stepwell consist of three levels. Each level is lined with arched niches on both sides. The well was quite interesting but  the locals only use it to sit and stay out of the sun. Most people were on their phones playing games. We did walk to the bottom and back.Our driver did have a few issues trying to fin it which we thought was odd as it is on the tourist brochure as a place of interest. Our driver was booked via our Hotel so I would have thought drivers would know most of the places tourists would visit.

Name: Siddarth Khare
Title: Worth visiting
Review: What a beauty in busy city.. It was a historic step well, Clean & Nicely mattened.. Good place to visit with family & friends. Just a suggestion because there is lot of waste water & due to that there are lots of mosquitoes. Good to carry some mosquitoes cream..

Name: sunnyonsports
Title: Not what I thought - BETTER THAN I COULD SEE
Review: hidden behind a bendy road, waiting rickshaw drivers and an ice cream cart...i walked into what seemed like a scene from Batman Dark Knight Rises...cool and calm, and a lingering smell of mold and bird poop. Go early or go late but this is ancient scene does more justice in real life than pictures. The history can be reviewed online, no need for a guide.Get some great pictures, and locals can help setup a great shot. Daring? Walk to the very bottom and look up! I batman dare you.

Name: Indu2510
Title: Simple and sweet
Review: Agrasen Ki Baoli is a small monument to visit. We happened to take the violet line and got off at janpath. From there, we took an auto, since it surely wasn't a walkable distance. Since we visited during the monsoons and also due to the presence of a small baoli- water tank within the monument, it surely was favourable season for mosquitoes. There are a series of steps leading you to the water tank or baoli but only to find plastic bottles thrown in the tank. The baoli has several angles to take good photographs and sit and enjoy on the steps. It may take about 30 to 45 minutes to complete your visit. From there, several autos are lined to take you to other nearby tourist destinations..Tip- if your planning to visit during monsoons, either wear full sleeves or apply good amount of mosquito repellent. One time visit that can be simple and sweet.

Name: The Author
Title: Spectacular
Review: Coming to Delhi as frequently as I do, this is one place that always seemed to evade me. Usually it is closed due to public holidays or I get there too late in the day. So, I was thrilled to finally get inside to take a look. The strangest thing about Agrasen Ki Baoli is it's location in a normal urbane street in the middle of the city within a 20 min walk from Connaught place. This is an ancient step well built by the king Agrasen. The mechanics and architecture of the well are truly breathtaking. The entrance is free and it's a great place to chill and people watch as well as do some writing and drawings (to catch up on your trip so far!). Most tour groups miss this small but quite amazing site out, so if your in Connaught place and have a few hours to kill, search for it on Google maps and it will direct you. Enjoy!

Name: Kaushik D
Title: A Historic Gem Hidden In The Urban Mess
Review: This isn't a monument. Just one of those rare engineering pieces that was used to quench a city's thirst, and till today, continues to be a calm, picturesque series of stone steps flanked by small alcoves on either side. Visit for that much needed adda with your squad, preferably during sunny mornings, or cool afternoons... and avoid during rainy days. And yeah...entry is free!!

Name: billyhockey
Title: Unique architecture
Review: Stepwells represent an original type of architecture and are found primarily in India and Pakistan. They were used to access groundwater but also stored rainwater. Given the resources that must have been required to construct such monumental architecture, it may be that stepwells had more than just a utilitarian function. In any event, it is remarkable to step away from the busy Hailey Road, and from the noisy horns of Delhi's cars and auto-rickshaws, and step into this peaceful baoil that may be more than 600 years old. The baoli, with three levels, multiple arches and over 100 steps to the bottom, is impressive. Entrance is free.

Name: Kalyan Peri
Title: Take time to visit this ancient step well!
Review: This ancient step well and protected monument is a very interesting place to visit & explore and snap some cool pictures!Bollywood seems to favor this place quite a lot possibly due to its unique architecture and historical charm!

Name: Gulzucker
Title: Mystery from ancient
Review: Many time have been in Delhi,  but never knew there is an amazing historical place full of mystery. Must see place if you are in Delhi.

Name: Connoisseur-of-Life
Title: Often Overlooked but Deserves to be Seen
Review: This impressive stepwell is worth a detour and not all that hard to find simply by Googling. You may be surprised by the physical effort required to walk to the bottom and back up. The bats give it added atmosphere. It is the perfect Kodak moment and seems to attract a steady stream of visitors. The mosque tomb at the top is also worth a quick explore. Auto rickshaws are parked outside ready for your custom.

Name: Arun Mani Kanta Gunda
Title: Mind blowing
Review: In the centre of cityLocal transport is availableAccess to metro alsoLooks like a masjidAlso like a place where treasure is hiddenBackground is superb

Name: surabhi_ms
Title: Superb architectural example in New Delhi ! Worth visiting once ..
Review: Situated in a very narrow lane and bit difficult to find it at one go but once you are here , you wont feel like leaving this place.. Always crowded by youngsters .It is a photographers delight ! Must visit this place if you are in Delhi .

Name: Julie B
Title: A little difficult to locate but worth the effort
Review: This Amazing well is in the heart of Delhi, but not that close to a metro - either a walk (thank goodness for phone maps) or a tuk-tuk ride. No entrance fee and very quite and tranquil place. You can walk down to the well, but the climb back up the steps is tiring in 40 degree heat so be warned. Nice place to visit

Name: Mark F
Title: Amazing
Review: This looks very little from the outside and is situated along a narrow lane but one you walk through the door all is revealed.  It is a step well and was used to store water for the summer months and the architecture is very clever and well worth seeing.You don't need long there, 15 minutes is probably fine.  Once inside there are a long flight of steps which take you down to the old water tank.

Name: Pradeep A
Title: Revisit history
Review: Situated in the narrow lane of Hailey Road, New Delhi. But the monument is very historic itself. Deep step type well below the stairs is amazing though it was now dry. There are so many points for photoshoot.

Name: pickytweeter
Title: Well worth a visit!
Review: Ancient stepwell- jaw dropping  when you put yr head thru the arch leading  to top of it! So steep and architecturally impressive. Best way to access it is by Hailey Rd..we came in via other side/direction - thru a very poor area and felt as if we might be lynched re- standing out so much as western women walking alone.

Name: Maneesh2700
Title: Beautiful gem of History
Review: A great place to be with friends and family, lots of opportunities for photo shoots ... worth spending some time to capture unforgettable memories

Name: Deepak DB
Title: Slice of History
Review: Baoli - Step Well in Hindi. Very close to CP is this historic Step Well. If you have a love of history, Moghul architecture then this place is must visit. As the name suggests its a step well hence be prepared to walk up and down steep rocky stairs to explore this historic place. It looks to be in good shape, couldn't explore much as we were not in shape to do the trek.

Name: Nidhi Gupta
Title: A place of historical as well as cultural importance
Review: A place of historical as well as cultural importance,located inthe heart of Delhi. very few visited this till its address was shared by Aamir Khan in movie PK. since then it has become popular but still the place is kept very clean and is an interesting tourist spot for people interested in history.

Name: Aline Hirano
Title: A well between buildings
Review: Hidden in the middle of a urbanized New Delhi, near the westernized Connaught Place and Rajiv Chowk, there is this step-well (baori), exhibiting a facade from older times where people would go down the steps to reach for water with buckets on their heads.Its a immersive experience that lets the turists to explore every inch of the place.The entrance is free, there are no facilities nearby, and besides the contemplation of the structure itself, there isn't much that can be done there; even though its a worthy experience that won't take much of a turist schedule.

Name: Madhur444
Title: Surreal Experience
Review: If you love History, get overwhelmed when you visit monuments, nostalgic when you can touch something which is thousand year old, this place is for you.

Name: Dev1972
Title: Step wells- nice place to visit in a short time
Review: This is a step well that served the old city of Delhi. There is a huge flight of stairs to the bottom of the well. So be ready for some workout if you want to see form the bottom. Can be explored in 15-20 minutes. Free entry. A little of the main areas of the city and is not that well patronised by visitors. But certainly worth a visit.

Name: vidushi jain
Title: Visit with family
Review: Agrasen Ki baoli is a preserved historical monument, it's a step well which was used to preserve water..You can visit here with friends and family, it's having step like structure and it's an ancient step well. There were rumors about this place that this place is haunted.

Name: Sparrowsx2
Title: Beautiful stepwell in Delhi
Review: The day that we went, there was almost no one there.  Very beautiful stepwell and it's open to the public / free to enter and walk around.

Name: John Burns
Title: Beautiful!
Review: Lovely architecture and an interesting history make this a good place to visit briefly.  Apparently it has been the film location for some blockbuster Bollywood movies to.  Also I read that it's haunted!

Name: PipPaul W
Title: Only one in Delhi
Review: We really wanted to see a stepwell in India and this is apparently the only one in Delhi. Not as spectacular as some we have seem in photos it is,  nevertheless worth getting to.Somewhat tucked away amd may take some finding. Free to enter

Name: Divsin0629
Title: wonderful
Review: Very unique experience because you deptth and the height and the beauty of the old thing and the new thing visible fowrax

Name: Souvik Saha
Title: Major historical gem within the metropolis
Review: This is major historical gem within the metropolis. The step well is very famous in Indian history and you can feel its grandeur.

Name: Shafaet A
Title: Historical stepwall
Review: This is a historical stepwall even though its not sure who built it and when it was built. Its a small place beside a narrow road. Good for a quick visit. There is a similar stepwall in old fort but that is much smaller.

Name: Mayank P
Title: Holiday
Review: Tucked away in the by lanes of New Delhi, far away from the chaos and noise of traffic, is the oasis of peace.  Attributed to the ancient King Agrasen (? Of Mahabharat vintage), this step well is a sight to behold.  Easy to reach, it's a haven of quiet and peace.  Do visit it if you have the time.

Name: Anika-gupta
Title: Amazing place yet too crowded!
Review: I went to this place which had always been on my list as a must-visit in Delhi. The place has beautiful architecture and is amazing. I was a little bored down by the crowd and the loud punjabi music playing somewhere closet bogged me down. Going further down till where it is allowed, helped and was soon used to the noise and the people didn't matter. I'm definitely going to visit this place again on a weekday, hoping for more calm atmosphere.

Name: JEAN B
Title: An amazing piece of architecture..
Review: Not far from Connaught Place in the centre of Delhi, behind an ordinary stone wall we were faced with one of the most amazing sights we had ever seen. It is almost impossible to describe the experience of walking through the entrance and being faced with this unbelievable piece of architecture. We’re used to looking up at architecture, not down into it, which adds to the sheer amazement and excitement when you see it. We saw several other below ground cisterns or stepwells as they are known in India, after this and were amazed by construction of them all.Agrasen Ki Baoli or Ugrasen Ki Baoli on the information block, a stepwell, is central Delhi’s oldest monument and still remains one of the best preserved Baolis in Delhi. The red-bricked monument is now protected under the Archeological Survey of India. It is 60-metres long and 15-metres wide.The monument has 105-108 steep steps (I lost count) with a series of carved arched chambers and passages on each side.  At the bottom there are several small openings that lead into what is now a dry well shaft. The flights of steps were originally excavated next to deep well shafts, ensuring that ground water could be reached all year longThousands of stepwells were built around India over a thousand years ago but most of them are now in total disrepair. Agrasen Ki Baoli can be found on Hailey Road near Connaught Place, Jantar Mantar in New Delhi.It is open 9 am to 5 pm and is free to enter. The nearest metro station  is Barakhamba Road the or Rajiv Chowk.

Name: G A
Title: Amazing Ancient Step Well In The Heart Of New Delhi
Review: Agrasen (or Ugrasen as the ASI board proclaims) ki Baoli is an amazing find in the heart of New Delhi.  Especially for those of us who havent seen that many old step wells before :)AKB is actually on Hailey LANE which is a narrow lane off Hailey Road near Mandi House.  The nondescript entrance is sort of opposite a plain building - maybe a school - with a large  colourful hard to miss wall mural.  As I said, the entrance is so nondescript that once you pass through the grill gate and look left, you are in for a shock!   This ancient stepwell apparently dates back to the 14th century or even earlier as per Wikipedia.   History aside,  it has loads of character and exudes the characteristic charm of all things ancient.    I first came here a few years ago when there were barely five other visitors apart from me and the site had an eerie feel in the backdrop of the then recent horrific Delhi gangrape that shocked the entire nation.   Now it was brimming with people, mostly college kids, young lovers and a smattering of tourists, with a decidedly cheerful ambience.This stone step well is a real gem that deserves a visit.  Not suitable for the disabled or those who have walking difficulties, or for children.  There are very many steep steps going all the way down to the actual rather dirty well, so it helps to wear sensible footwear and tread cautiously.  Apart from the ambience and the actual step well, there is also a khandhar   right on top where a bored ASI guard sits.AKB is very popular with the Time Pass crowd !No toilets and no food available inside.  Street food hawkers are available outside on Hailey Lane.PS:  What on earth is Leamigo???

Name: Jayanta Ray
Title: Amazing place
Review: This place is really amazing.Very beautiful place to take pics.The environment is thrilling.This is one of the haunted places in india.But dont worry ghost are nocturnal🤣🤣.

Name: Marcel B
Title: Best selfie place ever
Review: After lunch we drove to Agrasen Ki Baoli near Dailey Lane in New Delhi. Adress Hailey Road, Near Diwanchand Imaging Centre, K G Marg, Hamdard Nagar, Vakil Lane, Mandi House, New Delhi, Delhi 110001, IndiaThis is a surprising function in the heart of modern New Delhi, but it dates from before the new city by about 500 years and would have been used by the rural villages that once populated this area.Baoli is a feature of North India and was built to absorb seasonal fluctuations in the water supply, from the immense rainfall that fell during the monsoon season to the next periods of drought.A long staircase leads to the water level and the curved walls flank at the sides of the baoli. This is not only a water storage, but it is also a place to stay cool in warm weather. The architecture is typically late Tughlaq and the early Lodi dates from the mid-15th century. There is a small mosque at the entrance.

Name: Rahul D
Title: Wonderful Baoli
Review: If you are in Delhi and want to explore some new , exciting places then you should visit Agrasen ki Baoli. This place is fab located at the heart of the capital of India i.e Cannaught place. Here you can spend some quality time with your loved ones, click some great photographs and enjoy this beautiful and historical monument. Best time to visit is in the afternoon.

Name: Jen Mackenzie
Title: Stunning
Review: Luckily this is near where we were staying - but worth seeing for a half hour visit if you’re in Delhi.

Name: Nins
Title: Remarkable!!
Review: Located very close to CP this masterpiece can be reached by auto or Uber. The visiting hours are 0900-1700 and the entry is free. The architecture of this building is very fascinating and captivating. Great for taking photos. Had seen this place in PK movie for the first time and then when visited Delhi we made a point to visit this place.You will see many tourist, many students doing sketch of the architecture and its very remarkable!!Since it’s within the city limits it easily accessible, a must visit place.Personally, I love this place!!

Name: divertliving
Title: Hidden Gem of Delhi
Review: This is one our favorite place we have been so far in the city. This is a beautiful piece of history that is not crowded with people and is also free. By no means is this place huge but its well worth a visit and if you are into taking photos and learning history this is a not miss stop on your tour through Delhi.

Name: Tarique S
Title: HIDDEN HISTORIC POINT AMID BUSY CITY
Review: "Baoli" is referred to step well. It is located in the heart of New Delhi. If you have ample time in hand then you must visit this place. Good for photo shoot. However if you are running short of time then you can skip it. If Jaipur or Jodhpur is in your plan then you will find lots of such step well over there. Location wise, its very close to Rajiv Chowk Metro Station. Exit from Gate No 5 or Gate No 6. Janpath Metro stop is also nearby. There is no proper parking available outside the Baoli, so you have to park on road side. Entry is free.

Name: StratosLFC
Title: If you have time its worth to visit
Review: Designated and protected monument by the Archaeological Survey of India.Nice to see, and take pictures from the top of the stairs

Name: Tabrez K
Title: A piece if history
Review: The entrance is small but the baoli itself is big. tucked between residential buildings in one of the posh localities. There is no parking so better park in a safe parking place and take a rick to the place. There is no ticket. Lots of people visiting on a weekend. the well is dry but you can see the main well and the bathing pond clearly. Go during the day.

Name: SCD
Title: Careful where you park!
Review: Interesting place to visit. Well maintained - clean and graffiti free. Very popular. Make sure you go all the way to the bottom so that you can inspect the water tank. Be very careful where you park. The auto drivers won't tell you it is a no parking zone and there aren't any signs so when you return to see your car has been towed, the auto drivers then charge you a fortune. Speaking from experience!

Name: SangeetaSharmaJaifal
Title: Historically managed
Review: Good managed and clean place . Signs to see our old Indian places being managed by government. It’s nice to know about our old kings kingdoms and signs of life of kings .

Name: Marvin G
Title: A Step Well that is Architecturally Unique and Wonderful
Review: This step well, an underground structure that is used for the storage of water, was built by the Raja Ugrasen to help this area cope with seasonal fluctuations in the availability of water.  It was built with rubble and dressed stones and is one of the finest examples of baolis in Delhi.  Its main feature is a flight of 108 steps leading down to a very deep well.  The walls on both sides of the steps inset with a series of arches and corridors.There is a small mosque on a platform on the left side of the edifice as you descend to the well with a domed roof and columns made of sandstone.  People come here all the time to relax and take in the architectural wonders of this complex.  Shielded by trees and other plantings, it is a great place to visit on a hot and humid Delhi day.

Name: Adesitraveller
Title: Interesting venue right in the heart of the city
Review: We wanted to see this venue during our holiday. It is in a small bylane and it took us some time to locate it.The place is in a pretty good shape given its age and complete lack of protection from not just the elements but the misbehaving tourists as well. The steps are quite steep and there are no guide rails. Similarly, with all the teens pushing each other around, there is an accident waiting to happen.India has some wonderful monuments with far more history than most countries in the world. We should really take care of them.

Name: Arnab
Title: wonderful stepwell
Review: this is architecturally and symmetrically very beautiful. unfortunately its quite full of pigeons and their poop and not just that as you go down the steps you can smell the stench of the water and the bats on the ceiling dont add to the beauty either. but otherwise its a great place to spend the afternoon sunning in the delhi winter chill

Name: Nilisha Agarwal
Title: A beautiful place to hangout with friends and with yourself
Review: A place that was #lost for so many years in the heart of #Delhi which was found by a #bollywood movie #PK. .Agresen ki bowli is the place name and it is near to Cannaught Place (walkable). This place is one of the most haunted places in the city, and I can say that why. It have hundreds of bat inside it with a well inside it. There are stories around well , somewhere I read that water calls the name of person nearby and person then jumps off in water because it seems so beautiful to them. For me I felt, that anyone can slip into well because it's slippery and narrow.Go there, find out what do you think of this place.

Name: finejenny
Title: Wonderful architecture
Review: Historical water dwell shows the beauty of indian architecture, located just next to Connaught Place, a undermined sightseeing of Delhi, cannot be missed. the 60m x 15m step well is a instagramable landmark.

Name: Avik C
Title: A deep well right at the heart of the city
Review: Points deducted for the poor maintenance.This is an example of the amazing architecture of ancient India.You will certainly be stunned as soon as you enter the ancient reservoir. Partly because you will not be expecting what you will see. And mostly because of the sheer genius of the construction.The place can be better managed and can be turned to an awesome tourist attraction.Warning for people with vertigo as the steps are quite steep.

Name: DrSanjayDhawan
Title: Heritage site in the middle of modern development
Review: Historic deep step well in the middle of connought place with sky scrappers in the background. Very well preserved and just off Barakhamba Road. Worth a touristic visit

Name: Prachi235
Title: Hidden gem
Review: Very nice place for pictures. Its a hidden gem. Worth visiting. It’s very near to Connaught Place. Don’t miss

Name: Venkat G
Title: Hidden Architectural Gem
Review: Right in the heart of the city is this ancient water harvesting well with beautiful architecture. Featured in many movies and supposedly haunted you will love this place. Makes for beautiful pictures. Do not miss

Name: AakritiDhanawat
Title: It’s the best place to be with the history
Review: An out of the box place right at the center of the busy streets of Delhi. Super duper place to show someone who wants to see a heritage site in Delhi apart from the famous India Gate and Qutub Minar. Mind you the place is nowdays crowded with love birds and teenagers. This structure was built in 13-14 century though no one knows the exact date. I wish the Government maintains it nicely.

Name: Aparajita_03
Title: An old gem with new found popularity
Review: This ornate step well is located in a quiet locale of Hailey Road. However, after it was featured in the movie P. K. it has become immensely popular with the crowd. There was no place to stand on a Saturday. So the charm of the place came down a bit. You can visit if you are in CP and looking for something offbeat to do. However, coming dedicatedly for this is not recommended. You can spend about half an hour here if you want to go till the bottom of the well, but please be careful as the steps are old and uneven. Go when the weather is a bit cool as the rocks will get hot in summers.

Name: Miranda H
Title: Have to visit! Won't take long.
Review: Our tuk tuk driver took us here as Red Fort was closed - very tucked away & unassuming entrance then wow! You look down a massive set of steps down to the well at the bottom.  Teenage couples sitting all the way down.  An ancient feel but also a buzzy feel with all the kids.  Definitely worth a visit - by the time youve walked down & up again & taken some atmospheric photos it will only take 20 mins.  Purana Qila (old fort) & Ghandi monument are en route/close by so that was our afternoons itinerary.

Name: Devendra Yadav
Title: Ugrasen no baoli
Review: Actually a haunted stepwell close to connaught place new delhi,famous after movies like PK and sultan. Free entry but no parking.u will find a lot of pigeons and bats and offcourse crowded with people.good for clicking pics and one time visit.
